awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Environmental drivers of biodiversity: leveraging a history of NSF-funded research to test models of butterfly responses to global change
awd_abstract_narration:
Our most pressing ecological priority is to determine how human activity is driving global shifts in biodiversity and how we can balance preserving ecosystem function with the needs of a growing human population. The PI proposes new ecological research on the Pierid family of butterflies that have been the subject of research on thermal responses over the last 40 years.  The overarching goal of this research is to extend and generalize Species Distribution Models (SDM), the dominant modeling approach to understanding large-scale shifts of biodiversity in the face of global change.   The PI will leverage that 40 year legacy of thermal response research to develop general models of how butterflies respond to changing environments.  In order to verify how well these models perform and their ability to make both species-specific and general predictions, models will be validated with large-scale monitoring data sets.  There is a growing resource of citizen-science monitoring data but there are also several NSF-funded academic monitoring programs that have occurred over the years.  Another aspect of this project is to bring together those academic and citizen science data into a unified publicly-available data set.  The research is expected to advance macrosystems ecology study of thermal ecology and responses of biodiversity, especially ectotherms while also serving as a strong demonstration of data reuse by focusing on a well-studied and wide-spread group of butterfly species, the Pierids.
 

Research in macrosystems ecology requires two disparate ecological data types that are rarely generated or employed by the same research community: mechanistic, experimental data and data from large spatiotemporally-replicated monitoring programs. The two dominant environmental factors driving the distribution and abundance of butterflies are thermal environment (impacted by climate) and host-plant availability (impacted by land use change and climate). There are 14 previous and current NSF-funded projects focused on primarily thermal, but also nutritional drivers of performance in one family of butterflies, Pierids. Thermal environments have several impacts on butterfly performance. Indirectly, temperature drives the seasonal timing and distribution of host-plant (food) resources. It also provides energy for growth for developing caterpillars. Host-plants are also a key component of butterfly development, not just for the obvious reason that they acquire all their nutrition for growth from these plants, but the quality of the plants also determines their growth rate. There has been a long legacy of research on the thermal and nutritional constraints of growth for many insects, but these models have not yet been fully employed to make range-wide predictions for butterflies. We propose to bring together a legacy of NSF-funded research on butterfly responses to environmental change with long-term monitoring data that can be used, respectively, to generate and test mechanistic SDMs over multiple spatiotemporal scales.

This project is supported by the National Science Foundation?s Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Predicting species? responses to climate change at continent scales has recently become a key research goal. Insects are a primary focus because they are one of the most diverse and ecologically important taxa and are particularly sensitive to temperature. Our focus was on the insect order Lepidoptera, which includes butterflies and moths and comprises approximately 10% of all currently described species. Butterflies (and many moths) include some of the showiest insects so they are a rare group that is beloved by the public. However, many species also comprise some of the most destructive pests in agriculture and so understanding their response to changing environmental conditions has great economic importance. A common approach to studies of this kind has been to build thermal performance curves (TPCs). These TPCs are built from intensive laboratory studies where species are reared at different temperatures to mimic climate across a variety of biomes. Traditionally, these studies report only development time, a key metric for studies of seasonal emergence (important for crops and crop pests). However, many studies also collect data on survivorship across temperatures, but these results are often not emphasized or even presented in resulting publications. Yet, survivorship is a critical component for understanding population dynamics under past, current and future climates. Our goal was to compile data from past studies to construct developmental and survivorship TPCs using a consistent analytical approach. We used these combined TPCs to develop a novel framework for projecting and understanding organismal responses to climate change.

 

The Kingsolver lab at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill has been performing these experiments for 40 years, primarily to build TPCs for the butterfly sub-family Pieridae. We worked with the Kingsolver lab to collate their raw data from multiple research projects, most funded by NSF (IBN-0196132, IBN-0212798, DEB-1120062, IOS-1120500, DEB 5-37114, and IOS-1120500). In addition, we tapped into the literature reporting these results from other labs across the globe in order to cover all Lepidoptera. When possible, we compiled raw data (either from appendices or by contacting authors). Alternatively, we were often able to extract derived metrics from publications that constructed TPCs. We built a novel database from these studies that includes 1296 unique data sets of 119 species from 23 families and 137 localities across the globe.  We extracted key parameters- optimal temperature, thermal breadth, and lower and upper thermal limits-- from data on TPCs of development rate, survivorship, and their combination (performance). We found that typical TPC patterns differed for development (left-skewed) and survivorship (step functions at both cold and warm limits).  Threshold shifts across latitude differed among cold- and heat- tolerant species and upper limits were more conserved both among life stages and across latitudes than lower limits. This suggests more adaptive potential at the cold limits of species ranges.

 

In order to validate predictions of our model, we built a simulation of the spread of the invasive cabbage white butterfly (Pieris rapae) after its introduction to North America in 1859. The actual spread of this species during this period was extremely well documented, and the opportunity to validate hindcasts so far into the past is extremely rare. The simulation was based on development and survivorship TPCs using historical climate data across North America from 1860-1890. Our results showed that temperature alone was insufficient to explain the speed of spread of this species, but combining temperature with railway routes (that could facilitate spread), produced results that more closely matched observations. The potential to use other butterfly species to validate this approach is substantial because of the long history of public monitoring (so-called ?citizen science?) focused on butterflies. This validation process is now being continued for other butterfly species under new NSF funding (IOS- 2128241).

Another primary goal of this project was to make these data resources available to the public. All data used to build and implement our models was packaged in a public github repository. In addition, two platforms for the curation of butterfly monitoring data (butterflies.ucdavis.edu and pollardbase.org) were updated to provide maximum public access. We also provided code so others could implement these models and expand this research to other taxa. Our project was also valuable in expanding participation and training in data-intensive ecological research and data management for open science. The personnel leading work and mentorship were both underrepresented minorities in this field and they led the training of several undergraduate and graduate students using multi-level mentoring.  The collaboration between the Ries and Kingsolver labs provided experience in data reuse for new purposes and ended up leading to new interdisciplinary collaborations. Ultimately, this project demonstrates the value of leveraging historical data collected for one purpose to provide a basis for new research priorities.
